block.p: Williams-Sonoma Shares Are Hurt by Profit Warning Williams-Sonoma, the kitchen goods and home furnishings chain, said that its third-quarter profit would fall on lower-than-expected catalog sales and higher costs. The statement sent its shares down as much as 30 percent.

The company also said that its chief financial officer, John Tate, would resign as of Nov. 1 after just 18 months. Profit in the quarter that ends Oct. 29 will be 4 to 6 cents a share, down from 16 cents in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected 18 cents a share. [Page C19.]

Williams-Sonoma Shares Are Hurt by Profit Warning Williams-Sonoma, the kitchen goods and home furnishings chain, said that its third-quarter profit would fall on lower-than-expected catalog sales and higher costs. The statement sent its shares down as much as 30 percent.

The company also said that its chief financial officer, John Tate, would resign as of Nov. 1 after just 18 months. Profit in the quarter that ends Oct. 29 will be 4 to 6 cents a share, down from 16 cents in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected 18 cents a share. [Page C19.]

Drivers Undaunted by Gas Prices Over the last two years, energy prices have tripled again, but one would hardly know it from looking at America's roads. Few people have cut back sharply on their driving or have begun shopping for cars based primarily on fuel efficiency, according to interviews across the country and data from the government and auto industry. The nation is on pace to use almost the same amount of gasoline as it did last year, which was the most ever. [A1.]

Vodafone in Talks With Irish Giant The Vodafone Group is in talks with Eircom, Ireland's telecommunications conglomerate, about taking a majority stake in or buying all of Eircell, its mobile unit, people close to the discussions said. A bid for all of Eircell would probably be valued at 5 billion euros, or about $4.3 billion, these people said -- more than 80 percent of the market value of the entire parent company. [World Business, Section W.]

Stocks Edge Lower in Light Trading The Big Board had its slowest day in nearly two months as the Yom Kippur and Columbus Day holidays kept some investors away. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 28.11 points, to 10,568.43. The Nasdaq composite index declined 5.45 points, to 3,355.56, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.96 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,402.03. [C12.]

Rift Deepens in Canadian Labor Animosity between two of Canada's biggest union organizations, the Canadian Auto Workers union and the Canadian Labor Congress, an umbrella group that represents 2.4 million workers, has reached such a point that at last month's Labor Day celebration in Toronto, the auto workers boycotted the parade attended by other Labor Congress members and held a party elsewhere. [World Business, Section W.]

Call to Boycott 3 P.& G. Products The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John Sweeney, plans to ask consumers to boycott three products made by Procter & Gamble -- Tide laundry detergent, Crest toothpaste and Ivory soap -- to show support for actors who are on strike against the advertising industry. Union officials said Procter & Gamble was selected because it is one of the world's largest advertisers and because it has continued to make commercials during the strike using nonunion actors. [C2.]

Talks Stall on Urbanfetch Deal Negotiations for the acquisition of Urbanfetch.com, an online delivery service, by Kozmo.com, a rival, appear to have faltered at the 11th hour, officials close to the deal said. The difficulties came after agreement had been reached on the framework for a deal. [C2.]

Bulls, Bears and Bob Evans Bob Evans Farms, which owns a chain of restaurants and a sausage-making business, has been a target of shareholder wrath for its stagnant stock price, at $17 to $18 nearly unchanged since 1985. Annual meetings, centered on a picnic at the farm where the original Bob Evans got his start, have turned hostile, with investors demanding explanations from management, and management all but turning off the microphone. Market Place. [C10.]

First Worldwide Campaign for Kotex The first global campaign for Kotex seeks to surmount cultural, geographic and demographic boundaries by focusing on something women have in common: the need for feminine hygiene products. The campaign is the most recent in a category dominated by a handful of marketers. Advertising. [C9.]
